linkTarget.anchoringText: Many hydraulically-powered pumps for AL have been designed and operated in the course of the Industry. Several variations are described in Brown (1980), Fretwell (2007), and Pugh (2006), among others. This discussion will focus on the direct lineage of the SRVP in order from lower to higher maximum pumping volumes and operational depths (Furrow et al. 2012). Fig. 1 compares the theoretical production rates of the various Cormorant systems versus operational depths (Bolt 2012).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Theoretical production rates versus lifting depths for hydraulic systems in the direct SRVP lineage (after Bolt 2012).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Theoretical production rates versus lifting depths for hydraulic systems in the direct SRVP lineage (after Bolt 2012).

linkTarget.bib:
Bolt, 2012
D. J. Bolt
2012. Hydraulic Dewatering: Technology, Performance, and Applications . Presented at the Artificial Lift Research and Development Council (ALRDC) European Gas Well Deliquification Workshop, Groningen, The Netherlands, 24–26 September. http://www.alrdc.com/workshops/2012_2012europeangaswell/ Private/06%20EGWDC%202012%20Cormorant.pdf (accessed 14 June 2016).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SRVP is installed downhole inside a concentric tubing string and is powered by injecting a high pressure fluid. The injected (power) fluid causes a signal rod to extend/retract within a pilot-operated shuttle (engine) valve (Fig. 2). At the conclusion of the signal rod’s stroke, indentations in the signal rod cause the engine valve to shift from a “Home” to a “Forward” position or vice versa. The engine valve’s inlet/discharge flow paths are reversed in the Home/Forward configurations, allowing power fluid to be routed to the appropriate side of a power piston.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: SRVP engine valve housing drawing (left) and actual engine valve housing and shuttle (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: SRVP engine valve housing drawing (left) and actual engine valve housing and shuttle (right).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: actual engine valve housing and shuttle

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 3 diagrams the basic operating principles of the downhole SRVP. Fig. 3a describes the beginning of the “extend” stroke, with the engine valve in the Home position. Injected power fluid is routed through the engine valve to the top (left) of the power piston, forcing it to travel down (left-to-right). This movement exhausts spent power fluid around the power rod, back through the engine valve, and up the insert string by production tubing annulus.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: SRVP operational diagrams of the beginning of the extend stroke (a, top) and the end of the retract stroke (b, bottom).

formatted-caption.caption-text: SRVP operational diagrams of the beginning of the extend stroke (a, top) and the end of the retract stroke (b, bottom).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: SRVP operational diagrams of the beginning of the extend stroke

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 4 describes the operating envelopes for Type I/II AL methods and the SRVP in terms of gas production rate (Mscf/D) versus produced liquids (BFPD) at lifting depths of 8,000 and 12,000 ft-true vertical depth (TVD). A well with production characteristics towards the top left of the Fig. 4 graphs would be considered a “dry” well, while one with characteristics toward the lower right would be considered a “wet” well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Type I/II AL and SRVP operating envelopes in terms of produced gas and liquid rates. WGR is in units of bbl/MMscf.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type I/II AL and SRVP operating envelopes in terms of produced gas and liquid rates. WGR is in units of bbl/MMscf.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 5 shows daily (Mscf/D) and cumulative (MMscf) gas production versus time for a typical 3 Bcf tight gas well with a 30-year producing life (see Baihly et al. 2010, 2015 for other tight/shale gas examples). The reservoir pressure and producing rate of the well decrease when reserves are processed, causing the production rate to fall below the critical rate of 400 Mscf/D at approximately 5 years.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Daily and cumulative production versus time for a typical 3 Bcf tight gas well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Daily and cumulative production versus time for a typical 3 Bcf tight gas well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: If it has been determined that a gas well will require a Type II AL method, what options are available? Fig. 6a displays a subset of a Gas Well Unloading Selector from Weatherford (2009). If the Type I methods of plunger lift and are foam lift are ruled out, fluid power lift (jet pump), gas lift, electric submersible pump (ESP), and positive displacement lift remain. Weatherford. 2009. Deliquify Your Gas Wells: The Unloading Selector. Brochure, Weatherford, Houston, Texas, USA.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Gas Well Unloading Selector (a) and ESP and positive displacement lift systems flowchart (b) subset (Weatherford 2009).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas Well Unloading Selector (a) and ESP and positive displacement lift systems flowchart (b) subset (Weatherford 2009).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: ESP and positive displacement lift systems flowchart

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SRVP was piloted in a Western Colorado Piceance Basin (Fig. 7) well for deliquification operations. The objective was to pump fluids from a deep setting depth and later retrieve and redeploy the SRVP without a workover rig. This section will describe the pilot program, including the well characteristics, completion design, surface pumping skid, deployment and retrieval operations, performance and teardowns, learnings, and forward plans.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Piceance Basin map (U.S. Geological Survey 2003) with pilot field location indicated by star.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Piceance Basin map (U.S. Geological Survey 2003) with pilot field location indicated by star.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Table 3 summarizes the pilot well characteristics. The tight-gas Mesaverde was the producing formation. The Mesaverde is composed of interbedded, thinly-layered sands that can require many hydraulically fractured zones for processing (Adeyeye et al. 2013; Juranek et al. 2010; Matheney et al. 2013). A typical well in the field has several thousand feet of perforations and a deviated or “S”-shaped geometry. The pilot well’s geometry is diagrammed in Fig. 8.

Fig. 9 diagrams the pilot well’s completion. The production casing was 4.5 in. OD, 15.1 lbm/ft (3.826 in. ID), P110 grade to surface. The production tubing was 2.875 in. OD, 6.5 lbm/ft (2.441 in. ID), N80 grade with reduced-OD couplings because of the relatively small ID of the production casing. The 2.875-in. OD tubing was chosen to allow installation of a 2.063-in. OD, 3.25 lbm/ft (1.751 in. ID), L80 grade, flush-joint insert string that could accommodate either 238- or 278-series SRVPs because both models could use the same OD circulating seals.
Fig. 10 shows photos of the power fluid surface pumping skid, 2.063 in. OD stick pipe insert string, SRVP BHA with sealing cups and strainer, SRVP during a bucket test, and wellhead configuration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: From left to right: Power fluid pumping skid, 2.063 in. OD insert string tubing (above), SRVP BHA (below), bucket testing of SRVP, and pilot wellhead configuration.

formatted-caption.caption-text: From left to right: Power fluid pumping skid, 2.063 in. OD insert string tubing (above), SRVP BHA (below), bucket testing of SRVP, and pilot wellhead configuration.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 describes the injection fluid flow paths. Power fluid is injected through the upper left wing valve and master valve into the insert string for deployment and operation (Fig. 11a). Returning power and pumped fluids are produced up the insert string by production tubing annulus and out of the lower right wing valve. Gas is produced up the production tubing by production casing annulus and out of the casing valve (not shown).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Wellhead valving diagrams for SRVP deployment/ operation (a) and retrieval (b). Red “X” boxes indicate closed valves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellhead valving diagrams for SRVP deployment/ operation (a) and retrieval (b). Red “X” boxes indicate closed valves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was initially thought that each SRVP well would require an individual lubricator. However, it was found that the lubricator was only needed for deployment/retrieval operations and thus could be moved around a field as applicable. Fig. 12 shows a photo of the lubricator in place on the pilot well. A detailed diagram of the custom lubricator can be found in Romer et al. (2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Custom lubricator for SRVP installation/retrieval on wellhead of pilot well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Custom lubricator for SRVP installation/retrieval on wellhead of pilot well.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A brushed plunger was left on top of the SRVP to reduce the chance of debris falling around its top. Slickline (SL) magnet runs were performed after the plunger was removed to clean debris from the tubing. SRVP 1 was reverse-circulated with a pump truck at up to 0.75 bbl/min (10 gal/min) to nearly 2,100 ft-TVD in 1.5 hours, then tagged and pulled with SL. Pumping pressures encountered during SRVP 1 retrieval are plotted in Fig. 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Pumping rate versus reverse circulation pressure during SRVP 1 retrieval.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pumping rate versus reverse circulation pressure during SRVP 1 retrieval.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The third and final SRVP was deployed hydraulically with the surface pumping skid in 5 hours. The injection rates and pressures measured during deployment are plotted in Fig. 14. There is a clear indication that the SRVP seated when the injection pressure increased from nearly 400 psi for circulation to 1,100 psi for operation near the 5 hour mark.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Injection rate and pressure versus time during SRVP 3 deployment.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injection rate and pressure versus time during SRVP 3 deployment.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The performance of the three SRVPs in terms of cumulative volumes versus time is shown in Fig. 15. Power Water is the injected fluids, while Power + Produced Fluids is the sum of the injected and separated fluids. Net Produced Fluids is defined here as separated fluids minus injected power water so it includes pumped fluids and any that were produced up the casing with the gas because the Fig. 15 Power + Produced Fluids measurement was taken from the test separator.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative injection/production volumes and injection pressure versus time for SRVPs 1 through 3.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative injection/production volumes and injection pressure versus time for SRVPs 1 through 3.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 16 shows the performance of the SRVPs in terms of daily fluid rates versus time, in which the daily rates were normalized during the time periods between production reports. Net Pumped Fluids is defined as the insert string by production tubing annulus turbine meter measurement minus the injected power fluid turbine meter measurement. At times during the SRVP 3 testing there were contradictions between the test separator and annulus turbine meter measurements.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Per-day fluid rates and injected to net pumped fluid ratios for SRVPs 1 through 3.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Per-day fluid rates and injected to net pumped fluid ratios for SRVPs 1 through 3.

linkTarget.anchoringText: SRVP 1 inspection found that the engine valve, circulation valve, and water section were plugged with debris (Fig. 17). The debris appeared to include thread cuttings and corrosion-related products (e.g., an Xray diffraction analysis indicated FeCO3, likely from entrained CO2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: SRVP 1 circulation valve exterior and interior (left), engine valve housing (middle), and engine valve shuttle (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: SRVP 1 circulation valve exterior and interior (left), engine valve housing (middle), and engine valve shuttle (right).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: SRVP 1 circulation valve exterior and interior

linkTarget.anchoringText: SRVP 2 inspection found that the inlet side of the engine valve section was completely plugged with primarily quartz debris (Fig. 18). The debris appeared to have arrived in a large, catastrophic influx because the power and water sections were clear—the source was never identified. SRVP 2 components were again operational following cleaning.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: SRVP 2 engine valve housing (left), shuttle (middle), and debris (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: SRVP 2 engine valve housing (left), shuttle (middle), and debris (right).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SRVP 3 teardown uncovered some debris in the engine valve and some large material (suspected to be seal springs) that had entered the water section intake (Fig. 19). The combination of debris and water section blockage/wear likely resulted in reduced efficiency near the end of the pumping period. The SRVP components were operational following cleaning of the engine valve. The SRVP 3 engine valve was the same as was run in SRVP 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: SRVP 3 engine valve housing (left) and shuttle (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: SRVP 3 engine valve housing (left) and shuttle (right).
